body: @dubeejw As a sanity check, I checked build times for the go CLI in this travis build and another (we mainly do this for build time optimization, yes?). I noticed that it takes 2:33min in this build and exactly as long in another build without these changes. Would you investigate? Further above you noted a build time of 1:30min which doesn't seem to hold true any longer.
better proposal done in this pr: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1457
@csantanapr, anything else?
@mdeuser, if you're not too busy, can you take a look at this? No rush.
@trevorbodz, thanks for the information. Looks like the iOS SDK needs to be updated.

@trevorbodz in the FilterForecast action, can you change `func main(params:[String:Any]) -> [String:Any]` to be `func main(args:[String:Any]) -> [String:Any]`?  In the new CLI, Swift 3 is now the default and the name of the parameters in that runtime is "args"
There are three instances of `params` that must be changed to `args` in FileForecast.
Proposed Fix worked

@markusthoemmes, As a test, I did a couple of builds. The results are below. I think not cross-compiling the CLI does not save as much time anymore because a lot of changes have gone in to make the build faster. However, it looks like not cross-compiling the CLI does shave off a little bit of time from the build.

Do not cross-compile CLI:

```
./gradlew tools:cli:distDocker
Total time: 49.633 secs
```

Cross-compile CLI:

```
./gradlew tools:cli:distDocker -PcrossCompileCLI=true
Total time: 1 mins 23.203 secs
```

Reverted to use 2s in the code, and changed the doc to match.
@ind1go LGTM, thanks for the PR

The code for this has been pushed and we are undergoing stress testing.  Because it's a fundamental change, I will keep this open until we see evidence that this is working as designed when under load.
@ddragosd Have you tested this with a swarm cluster - in theory pointing this compose install to a swarm cluster and having it push Whisk there?
@ddragosd, can you confirm that this PR helps your build issues?

@paulcastro Since swift has to compile code, if the compile fails, then it would have been nice if my action creation (same with update) failed (instead of success) so that I know immediately that I have an issue with bad code and I don't have to wait for the code to run and then dig through activations/logs. Also, prevents me from deploying bad code to OpenWhisk Let me know if that should be a new issue.

The code actually compiles on the first run, not on the action create.  This is the case for the other runtimes, too. I believe having the code compiled on create would involve a lot of changes.  This is likely something we would do in a significant update to how the platform operates.
rebased and merged in 306cac858fcc1ac4da6d58f7292d981264992787

@paulcastro This concerns me a bit. If I understand correctly, this code compiles and runs well on the Swift 2 runtime, but not on Swift 3. If that is true, then why does the Swift 3 runtime expect a different label for the `main` function argument? Wouldn't this same change be required for _all_ actions that are being transitioned from the Swift 2 runtime?

Swift 3 started enforcing argument labels so `main(args: [String:Any])` has to be called using `main(args: ["name":"Joe"])`.  In Swift 2 you didn't have to specify the label and could do `main(["name":"Joe"])`.  We call `main` in epilogue.swift so we had to fix the label to args.

The other option is to change the signature of the Swift action to `main(_ anything: [String:Any])`.  I don't like the underscore though. I recall seeing a proposal for Swift 3 that dropped the argument labels entirely when calling a function but I don't see that in the current release.

ah... I see now. So this code was using `params` as the label (and possibly getting away with it) when we have been suggesting the `args` label all along. My only concern was if there were lots of existing Swift 2 actions that were using `params`, but that does not actually seem to be the case.

Thanks for clarifying.
Yes, we will deprecate Swift 2 (issue #1459 )

@rabbah, even when the URL is correct, the backend is not returning the error that you mentioned. For example, when creating an action with just `/` as the name, the following URL should be generated. Note that the URL is missing an action name after `/actions/`.

```
https://{deployment_address}/api/v1/namespaces/{namespace}/actions/?overwrite=false
```

Here is the error returned from the server:

```
error: Unable to create action: HTTP method not allowed, supported methods: GET, OPTIONS (code 310776)
```

As you can see the illegal character error was not returned. Perhaps some changes to the backend need to be made to generate the desired error. Obviously we can detect this situation with the CLI, and generate the proper error message with the CLI. However, this does not help in the case where user is not using the CLI to create actions, etc.

I don't follow - the URL that is sent to the controller is wrong (ignores the dot for example). So I don't understand this comment "As you can see the illegal character error was not returned.".

 The error that's returned for `https://{deployment_address}/api/v1/namespaces/{namespace}/actions/` is expected. You can only GET on that URI (it lists the actions in a package).

For the dot example, Go's built-in URL encoding is removing the dot. This happens if you put the correct URL into your browser as well. I can probably find a workaround for that.

I suppose the CLI will need to throw an error before the HTTPS request is made if the action name is just a forward slash .
@starpit please review the test changes. @markusthoemmes deferring to you to merge; comments addressed and pg tag pending.
the names of entities aren't uri encoded?
i think this is an accurate port from the hellish bash script. should the PR include eliminating bash script, or that script still useful for standalone testing?

Entity names are being URI encoded. It appears that the `/.?` sequence is equivalent to `/?` when requests are made via HTTP(S). This seems to be true even when I try it out in a browser.

I can throw errors when the two mentioned cases occur (dot and slash), but the error will not contain a sequence number. Ie, you would just get `error: Unable to create action: name '.' contains illegal characters` without the `(code ...)` part.

What is the timeline for implementing the NPM solution? As it currently stands, anyone with existing Node actions that want to make use of the `whisk` object and the zip feature are faced with the task of rewriting their code.

While I think that having an NPM module is a good long term solution, it seems like we should fix this now, even temporarily, to enable people to use the zip feature.

@rabbah, why is it that I can create action names with an "illegal character" when said character is not at the front of the entity name? For instance, I can create an action with a name of `action@name`. However, I cannot create an action with a name of `@name`.
This is the regex for allowed names https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/common/scala/src/main/scala/whisk/core/entity/EntityPath.scala#L157.
rebased and merged in 8d747fa1d4e1cfee496cfe6f568876389487e372
This will be fixed with the new implementation. Since this is quite close I think it's not worth fixing with the existing implementation.
What is the issue number of that fix? I am having this issue in my implementation and I'd love to keep track of when it is fixed :)

Changed the model to follow zip file uploads used in nodejs and dropped tgz support in favor of having just one format. This changes the flow slightly to:

```
on host:
# cd /Users/Shared
# docker run -v /Users/Shared/:/workspace -it dockerskeleton bash

now inside container
# cd /workspace
# apk add --no-cache bzip2-dev gcc libc-dev zip
# echo '#include <stdio.h>
int main(int argc, char *argv[]) { printf("hello blackbox\n"); printf("%s\n", argv[1]); }' > bb.c
# gcc -o exec -static bb.c
# zip bb.zip exec

exit container to return to host /Users/Shared
# wsk action create bb --docker bb.zip
ok: created action bb
# wsk action invoke bb --blocking --result -p msg hello
{
    "msg": "hello"
}
```

Because the CLI fills in the docker image and it's our own, then we know we can 1. skip puling the image, and 2. the logs will be sentinelled.

```
"logs": [
        "2016-08-31T03:45:48.449739089Z stdout: hello blackbox",
]
```

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/995.

Are you using openwhisk on bluemix or your own deployment? If the latter, I can suggest a workaround.
I am using openwhisk on bluemix. At the moment as a work around I am implementing to trigger the sequence multiple times with different configuration so that the long running action runs under 1 min.

for local dev with pr:

```
> time docker  --host 192.168.99.100:4243 build --no-cache --build-arg CLI_OS=mac --build-arg CLI_ARCH=amd64 -t cli openwhisk/tools/cli 
       48.67 real         0.01 user         0.01 sys
```

and without pr:

```
> \time docker  --host 192.168.99.100:4243 build --no-cache -t cli openwhisk/tools/cli 
      110.44 real         0.03 user         0.03 sys
```

On a slow connection, this is even worse. I favor adopting this. If the complexity for the blue deployment is mitigated by flipping the defaults, I'm ok with that too if we can stuff the bits into `wskdev`.
Yep we agreed to adopt it, just a matter of me merging all the dependencies. Will get to it ASAP.
@rabbah - Just confirming.  Upon action creation, when `code` is empty, should it be removed from the request body?

It could be omitted but this one is harmless on PUT in that the controller ignores it correctly. The confusing one is on the get: the CLI is showing a code property that doesn't actually exist in the schema.

@bjustin-ibm @dubeejw @csantanapr As we discussed for the feed action and trigger action important for object storage, I believe that we also need to initialize the openwhisk environment with a database saving the relationship between triggers and containers, and install the feed and trigger for object storage if this service will be launched.
Do we expect to document this as officially supported? If so, it would be good to have an example that does _something_ with the incoming JSON.

let's keep the approach that we have today to keep the code in this repo "openwhisk" very generic and not specific to the details of the package.
We already have something in place to install actions, let's use same approach.
from ansible:
Git clone package-x
deploy:
run package-x/installActions.sh arg1 arg2 arg3 ...
run package-x/configureDB.sh arg1 arg2 arg3 ...
clean:
run package-x/deleteActions.sh arg1 arg2 arg3 ...
run package-x/unconfigureDB.sh arg1 arg2 arg3 ...

Haven't we discussed at least briefly to store information like this right on the trigger?

I guess I don't understand the specific requirement to have a separate database here. Could you elaborate a bit more?

@rabbah, I am able to omit the code field if it is empty. There are several tests failures that result though. These are related to NodeJS actions being created without a code field. The backend expects at least an empty string for NodeJS action code.
Looks like the failures are due to tests using a js file that has no code in it.

I have a build that will refuse to create an action of kind swift (representing swift:2), and will not invoke any existing action of swift.  This is all done at the invoker level, I can look into moving this up to the controller if it makes more sense.

This illustrates the problem with encoding the schema/types in the CLI - they're inconsistent wrt the API and complicate the CLI implementation. The `code` property exists for nodejs and other runtimes but not docker actions.
Is there a basic example for deploying a java application somewhere yet ?
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions.md#creating-java-actions

did you consider moving all the sequence scheduling code to its own trait? (which then you can test for all the corner cases perhaps).

re this: >  remove old sequence code (and fix tests that check for pipe.js specific things)
can we have a feature toggle so that we can back out the switch if needed and then when were sure cleanup in a new pr.

This is related to #512 where we might drop activation records for triggers altogether (and we're entertaining dropping the payload content for triggers already).
@rabbah, can you list the steps to reproduce the null result field? I am able to duplicate the issue by just using a trigger with no rule.

The trigger activation has a `result` property that records the event details. This can be potentially large and compounded by the number of triggers will have a large footprint. As a short term action: remove the payload from the activation for triggers.

@sjfink @jthomas FYI.

`wsk trigger create t`
`wsk action create a --docker a`
`wsk rule create r t a`
`wsk trigger fire t`

now check activation for r, you'll see null (same as trigger as you noted).

```
list all actions
Usage:

Flags:

```

the `-l` doc is not accurate for list.
